speaker: Anton Klotz
title: Cadence University Program and Open Source Hardware
abstract: Cadence University Program is used worldwide by more than 1000 universities. Cadence is providing around 162 tools within the program to the students and academic staff for very low membership fee. The academic licenses, which are provided, have certain legal restrictions, which are currently not compatible with the creation of Open Source Hardware. In the talk Cadence University Program Manager EMEA, Anton Klotz, will propose a way, how the academic terms and conditions can be changed in order to become compatible with Open Source Hardware, while protecting Cadence commercial interests.

speaker: Luis Felipe R. Murillo
affiliation: Data Science Institute, University of Virginia
title: HOWTO create a culture of hardware sharing in academia
abstract:
In this presentation I will introduce the "Journal of Open Hardware" to
discuss the promises and challenges of creating a culture of hardware
sharing in academia. First, I will describe the publication format we
devised ("HW metapaper") for documenting open scientific instruments.
Then, I will explain the importance of creating a library of "prior art"
for future hardware projects. For the conclusion, I will examine the
challenges of documenting and publishing hardware based on actual papers
from various disciplines, including but not limited to bioengineering,
management, economics, and education.

speaker: Tim Edwards
title: Protecting proprietary data in an open environment
abstract:
There is a clear disconnect between "open hardware" visible to all,
and all the foundry and EDA tool proprietary data and formats that
comprise the final, fabricated design.  This raises the serious
question of whether it is even possible to have "open hardware"
beyond RTL.  I will discuss the efabless, Inc. model, the challenge
of protecting proprietary information on an otherwise open platform,
and what measures we have taken to secure the blessing of foundries.

speaker: Tim Edwards
title: Bootstrapping a real working design flow
abstract:
The Open Circuit Design tool "qflow" is considered by some to be the
only real, working, completely open source verilog-to-GDS flow available
today, for all its limitations and dependence on legacy software.  I
will describe the history of qflow, how this working tool flow has been
bootstrapped from bits and pieces of open source software, and where
it will be going in the (near) future.

speaker: Philipp Wagner
title: Cocotb: Python-powered hardware verification

speaker: Matt Venn, Clifford Wolf
title: Introduction to Formal Verification with Symbiotic EDA Open Source Tools
abstract:
Experience some of the benefits of formal verification with this presentation and demo. You will
be introduced to the concept of formal verification and learn the basics of how to use the Open Source Tools
to verify your designs. We will go on to demonstrate using formal properties to validate a bus peripheral and a pipeline.
